abstract.text: 17 Aim: To accumulate evidence that indicates the key role played by virus-triggered 18 inflammation in the 2019-novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) which emerged in Wuhan 19 City and rapidly spread throughout China. 20 Methods: Age, neutrophil(NEU)-to-lymphocyte (LYM) ratio (NLR), 21 lymphocyte-to-monocyte(MON) ratio, platelet-to-lymphocyte ratio(PLR), and C-reactive 22 protein(CRP) of 93 patients with laboratory confirmed COVID-19 were investigated and 23 compared. The receiver operating characteristic curve was applied to determine the 24 thresholds for five bio-markers, and their prognostic values were assessed via the Kaplan-25 Meier curve and multivariate COX regression models.

26 Results: The median age was 46.4 years old, and 37cases were females. A total of 26.8% 27 of patients had been to Wuhan, and 73.1% had contacted with people from Wuhan. Fever 28 (83.8%) and cough (70.9%) were the two most common symptoms. Elevated NLR and age 29 were significantly associated with illness severity. The binary logistic analysis identified 30 elevated NLR (hazard risk [HR] 2.46, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.98-4.57) and age 31 (HR 2.52, 95% CI 1.65-4.83) as independent factors for poor clinical outcome of 32 COVID-19. NLR exhibited the largest area under the curve at 0.841, with the highest 33 specificity (63.6%) and sensitivity (88%). 34 Conclusions: Elevated age and NLR can be considered independent biomarkers for 35 indicating poor clinical outcomes. 36

FIGREF0.text: December 2019, several cases of pneumonia of unknown etiology have been 40 reported in Wuhan, Hubei province, China [1]. On January 7, 2020, the Chinese Center for 41 Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has revealed a novel beta-coronavirus from the 42 throat swab sample of a patient through high-throughput sequencing [2]. The disease 43 resembles severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) [3] and has been 44 subsequently named the 2019-novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) by the World Health 45 Organization (WHO). Evidence pointing to the person-to-person transmission has occurred 46 among close contacts in hospital and family [4,5]. Considerable efforts for reducing 47 transmission are required to control outbreaks. Coronaviruses, such as SARS-CoV [6] and 48 MERS-CoV[7], can cause multiple system infections in various animals and mainly induce 49 respiratory tract infections in humans [6]. Most patients exhibited mild symptoms and 50 partial patients exhibited worse prognosis. To date, only a few COVID-19 patients have 51 developed into severe pneumonia, pulmonary edema, acute respiratory distress syndrome 52 [1,7], or multiple organ failure and eventually died. Given the rapid spread and serious 53 harm of COVID-19, it is urgent to continuously improve and enrich its clinical diagnosis 54 and treatment research. This updated analysis identified the defining laboratory results and 55 clinical characteristics with improved precision and also elucidated the risk in the progression of various viral pneumonia, including COVID-19 59 [8]. Severe inflammatory responses contribute to weak adaptive immune response, 60 thereby resulting in immune response imbalance. Therefore, circulating biomarkers 61 that can represent inflammation and immune status are potential predictors for the 62 prognosis of COVID-19 patients [9]. Peripheral white blood cell (WBC) count, 63 neutrophil (NEU)-to-lymphocyte (LYM) ratio (NLR), derived NLR ratio (d-NLR, 64 neutrophil count divided by the result of WBC count minus neutrophil count), 65 platelet-to-lymphocyte ratio (PLR). and lymphocyte-to-monocyte ratio (LMR) are 66 indicators of the systematic inflammatory response [10] that are widely investigated 67 as useful predictors for the prognosis of patients with viral pneumonia. By collecting 68 the data from 93 laboratory-confirmed cases, we attempted to determine the effect of 69 sex, age, CRP, WBC count, NLR, LMR, PLR, and co morbidities on the length a retrospective study on the clinical characteristics of laboratory 74 confirmed cases with COVID-19. Patients with complete clinical data, including 69 75 non-severe and 24 severe cases, were randomly selected. Cases were diagnosed on the 76 basis of the interim guidance of the World Health Organization (WHO) [5] and 77 diagnosis and treatment guidelines of COVID-19 in China[8]. non-severe patients met 78 all following conditions: (1) Epidemiology history, (2) Fever or other respiratory 79 symptoms, (3) Typical CT image abnormities of viral pneumonia, and (4) Positive 80 result of RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Severe patients additionally met at least 81 one of the following conditions: (1) Shortness of breath, RR≥30 times/min, (2) 82 Oxygen saturation (Resting state) ≤93%, or (3) PaO2 / FiO2 ≤300mmHg. the analysis.The imperative of informed consent was waived in light of 87 the anonymous, retrospective, and observational character of this study. . 88 Clinical characteristics and laboratory data 89 Epidemiological characteristics, including recent exposure history, clinical symptoms and 90 signs, and laboratory findings, were obtained from electronic medical records and 91 telephone confirmation. Laboratory assessments consisted of complete blood count, blood 92 chemistry and CRP. The severity of COVID-19 was defined on the basis of international 93 guidelines for community-acquired pneumonia. First, the endpoint of non-severe time 94 (NST) was the admission to the intensive care unit (ICU), cure and discharge, or 95 mechanical ventilation. Second, severe time was defined as the time from observation of 96 severe illness to the date of death, symptom reduction redefined as mild, or the end point 97 time of follow-up until February 20, 2020. Given that clinical observations are still ongoing, 98 a fixed time frame, that is, within 28 days, has not been applied to these endpoints. 99 Statistical analysis 100 Continuous variables were expressed as the appropriate means and standard deviations or 101 medians and interquartile ranges. Categorical variables were summarized as the counts and 102 percentages in each category. We grouped the patients into severe and non-severe 103 COVID-19 ARD according to the interim guidance of the World Health Organization 104 (WHO) [5] and diagnosis and treatment guidelines of COVID-19 in China[5,8], which 105 includes the clinical management of severe acute respiratory infection in suspected cases. 106 Wilcoxon rank sum tests were applied to continuous variables, and chi-square and Fisher's 107 exact tests were used for categorical variables. The optimal cut-off values of the continuous 108 NLR, d-NLR, PLR, and LMR were calculated by applying the receiver operating curve 109 (ROC) analysis [16]. Hazard risk (HR) and 95% confidence interval (CI) were used as 110 common measures to assess relative risk. Enter elimination binary logistic regression 111 analysis was conducted to determine the influence of age, gender, and all other significant 112 factors. P<0.05 was recognized as statistically significant. All these statistical calculations 113 were performed using the SPSS 17.0 software (SPSS Inc, Chicago, USA). 114 Results 115 Results of WBC count, NLR, LMR, PLR, CRP, d-NLR, and clinical characteristics in 116 the study subjects.

At the end date of data collection (2020-02-18), more than 70000 cases of 203 COVID-19 were confirmed, and 1800 cases died. Mortality was less than 2.5% (CDC, 204 China). In recent publications [1,8], the clinical characteristics of COVID-19 are 205 similar to those of SARS-CoV. Fever and cough were the dominant symptoms, 206 whereas gastrointestinal symptoms were rare, suggesting the difference in viral 207 tropism compared with SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, and influenza [11]. Fever occurred 208 in only 43.8% of patients on initial presentation and developed in 83.4% after 209 hospitalization. The absence of fever in COVID-19 was more frequent than in 210 SARS-CoV (1%) and MERS-CoV infection (2%) [6,12], and such patients may be 211 missed if the surveillance case definition focused heavily on fever detection [13]. 212 Consistent with the two recent reports [14], lymphopenia is common and severe in 213 some cases. Significantly high frequencies of severe cases were observed in elder 214 patients with diabetes or hypertension (Tables 1). The clinical characteristics of these 215 patients are similar to those reported in previous studies.[2,3,18]. 216 After the discussion of the clinical features of COVID-19, we analyzed the 217 immunological characteristics of peripheral blood in patients with COVID-19. In the 218 present study, our results first proved our hypothesis and indicated that elevated NLR was 219 an independent prognostic biomarker that affected pneumonia progression in COVID-19 220 patients. In addition, the integration of elevated neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio(NLR) to 221 prognostic nomograms may lead to improved prediction. Our findings were consistent with 222 those of previous studies on the relationship between NLR and prognosis of many other 223 infectious diseases [15]. The following reasons may account for the findings. On the one 224 hand, neutrophil (NEU)is a major component of leukocyte population that activates and 225 migrates from the venous system to the immune organ or system. NEU releases large 226 amounts of reactive oxygen species that can induce cell DNA damage and free the virus 227 from the cells. Thus, antibody dependent cell mediated cell(ADCC)may kill the virus 228 directly, expose virus antigen, and stimulate cell-specific and humoral immunities [16].
